content:
Diagnosis:
Locally advanced laryngeal squamous cell carcinoma with metastatic progression

Initial Staging:
T4aN2cM0 SCC larynx diagnosed January 2024
p16 negative, PDL1 CPS 50

Treatment History:
Jan-Feb 2024 - Radical chemoradiotherapy (70Gy/35#) with concurrent cisplatin
March 2024 - CT showing new pulmonary nodules and T8 vertebral metastasis
April 2024 - Commenced pembrolizumab monotherapy

Previous Medical History:
Type 2 diabetes
Hypertension
Chronic kidney disease stage 3

Current Medications:
Pembrolizumab 200mg q3weekly
Dexamethasone 4mg bd
Oxycodone MR 30mg bd
Oxycodone IR 5mg prn
Metformin 1g bd
Ramipril 5mg od

Current Situation:
Progressive disease with new liver metastases

I reviewed [redacted name] today who has unfortunately experienced significant clinical deterioration over the past three weeks. He reports worsening pain in his mid-back despite increased analgesia, new right upper quadrant discomfort, and increasing fatigue limiting him to short walks around the house. His voice quality has deteriorated with increasing hoarseness and some mild stridor at rest. He has lost a further 3kg in weight despite nutritional supplements.

CT scan performed yesterday shows multiple new liver metastases, progression of pulmonary metastases, and increasing size of T8 vertebral deposit with early cord compression. The primary laryngeal tumor shows local progression with increasing subglottic extension.

Performance status has declined to ECOG 2-3. On examination, he is cachectic with obvious stridor at rest. There is tender hepatomegaly extending 4cm below the costal margin. Neurological examination shows early signs of cord compression with increased tone in lower limbs but preserved power and reflexes.

I have discussed these findings with [redacted name] and his wife today. Given the rapid progression through immunotherapy and declining performance status, I have explained that further systemic anti-cancer therapy is unlikely to be beneficial and carries significant risks. We have agreed to focus on symptom control and quality of life.

Plan:
1. Urgent MRI spine to fully assess cord compression
2. Referral to clinical oncology for consideration of palliative radiotherapy to T8
3. Urgent referral to palliative care team
4. Discontinue pembrolizumab
5. Increase dexamethasone to 8mg bd
6. ENT review regarding consideration of tracheostomy
7. Follow up with palliative care team next week
8. Provide acute oncology contact details

primary_cancer.metastases: multiple liver metastases, pulmonary metastases, T8 vertebral metastasis

cancer_timeline.value: Started radical chemoradiotherapy with concurrent cisplatin
CT showing new pulmonary nodules and T8 vertebral metastasis
CT shows multiple new liver metastases, progression of pulmonary metastases, increasing T8 vertebral deposit with early cord compression, primary tumor progression
Discontinuing pembrolizumab due to disease progression and declining performance status

patient_facts.value: Deteriorating voice quality with hoarseness and mild stridor
Cachectic with stridor at rest, tender hepatomegaly 4cm below costal margin, increased tone in lower limbs

status_updates.value: Advanced laryngeal cancer with rapid progression through immunotherapy and new metastases. Significant clinical deterioration with declining performance status necessitating switch to palliative approach
Disease progression on pembrolizumab with new liver metastases and worsening existing disease
Deterioration to ECOG PS 2-3 with mobility now limited to short walks around house
Discontinuing pembrolizumab and switching to palliative approach
Urgent MRI spine to assess cord compression
Urgent referral to palliative care team with review next week, referral to clinical oncology for palliative radiotherapy, ENT review regarding tracheostomy
